The article discusses the vaccine being developed to prevent the Zika virus, and how it is hoped it will be available to pregnant women in November.

Adult social care services are facing a £1.1bn shortfall this year, on top of "almost unendurable" cuts since 2010. Budgets for adult social care - which provides practical support to people due to illness, disability, old age or a low income - will reduce by a further £500m in cash terms this year, the report warns. Some councils have made savings in the past by freezing fees paid to providers, but care providers are now also facing financial problems. Ministers say extra money will help NHS and social care services work together.

The new study shows that even if emissions of warming gases ceased immediately, the limit of 1.5 degrees Celsius for global temperature increase would be breached over land. This would have serious implications for the economy and for the planet.

Sir Timothy O'Shea, the rector of one of Scotland's ancient universities, has voiced concern over proposed amendments to the Higher Education Governance Bill which he believes could damage the institution. The bill aims to improve the way universities - which are fiercely protective of their independence from the state - are governed, but Sir Timothy believes the amendments would allow for two elected positions playing a chairing role in the university - a rector and a senior lay member. He argues that the senior lay member would appear to have significantly weaker powers than their counterparts at other universities - without any prior consultation or discussion. If the amendments are passed, Sir Timothy fears that the university's institutional autonomy could be compromised.

The article discusses the involvement of two DUP special advisers in the Renewable Heat Incentive, which has been subject to allegations of corruption. The article claims that neither of the advisers have any connection to the poultry industry, and that their only involvement is in advising the economy minister.

Fidel Castro was a revolutionary who led Cuba for 47 years. He is known for his beliefs in communism and his opposition to the United States. He has been praised for his efforts to make Cuba a more equal society, but he is also condemned for keeping his people poor and for his intolerance. Fidel Castro stopped his people from leaving the island, leading them to risk their lives in rickety boats to try to get out. At one stage in the early years of the Reagan administration he was accused of trying to take over Central America for the Soviet Union by revolution. Washington at that time saw a path that led from the guerrillas of El Salvador through Nicaragua to Cuba and right up to the door of the Kremlin. Cuban assistance to the small and then revolutionary island of Grenada in the Caribbean prompted a full-scale US invasion. Throughout his rule, President Castro remained in almost permanent confrontation with the United States - and it with him. The American embargo on Cuba has been used by both sides - as a policy by the US to isolate Cuba and as an excuse by Fidel Castro for the island's poverty.
The first day of the trial of disgraced Chinese politician Bo Xilai ended with him defiantly denying bribery charges.

Amidst the tributes and flowers left in St Ann's Square following the Manchester Arena attack, many people are still undecided on the best way to move forward. Some believe the election should be put on hold, while others believe that politics must resume as usual.

Many people who would benefit from palliative care are not getting it, according to a new report. Despite this, London sees the majority of its pupils receiving a place at their first preference. NI's public services college has been embroiled in controversy for years, with funding for the proposed joint college eventually being withdrawn. The preferred option is for the fire service to have a training facility at Desertcreat at an estimated cost of £44m.

The Youth Olympics, which takes place in Lillehammer, Norway this year, offers athletes aged between 15 and 18 the opportunity to compete in a range of sports. Many venues from the 1994 Winter Olympics have been refurbished for the event, which is aimed at providing participants with an early introduction to the multi-sport environment.

The Equality and Human Rights Commission has expressed concern about the increasing number of hate crimes in the UK since the country voted to leave the EU. They believe that politicians need to take a more nuanced approach to debating big issues, and that more concerted action is needed to address the issue.

Jayalalithaa rose to prominence as an actress in the late 1960s before entering politics in the early 1990s. She was elected to the Tamil Nadu Assembly in 1989 and became the first woman opposition leader. She championed the cause of the rural and urban poor by introducing subsidised food canteens, providing free laptops to thousands of school pupils and students and launching other populist schemes like giving away food mixers and grinders to families. She attracted a level of support that verged on the bizarre, with some followers professing loyalty through acts such as walking on hot coals or drawing her portrait with their blood. In 2011 she was elected chief minister of Tamil Nadu for a third term, but her tenure was swiftly ended after allegations of corruption. She was later reinstated as chief minister, but was removed from office again in 2015 after being convicted of using her position to amass a huge property portfolio.

Jonathan Calderwood, the head groundsman at Paris Saint-Germain, is a native of Ballymena in County Antrim, and he has received recognition from some of the world's best footballers for his work on the pitch.

People in the audience at the Cardiff University event 'Remembering, Forgetting and Moving On' felt moved to stand up and share their own stories of the 1966 coal waste tip tragedy that killed 116 children and 28 adults. Yvonne Price from Merthyr Tydfil, one of the first four police officers at the scene, recounted her experience of the day of the disaster, when she had to climb through a window into the school as the only person there small enough to do so. Other speakers included Jeff Edwards, survivor and council leader, and Steve Gerlach, one of the three siblings who survived. The community is still dealing with the aftermath of the tragedy, 50 years later.
